S1.SS2.31.table:
Definition Notation
Number of edge servers N𝑁N
Number of clients for each edge server J𝐽J
Global model of the cloud server 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}
Edge global model of i𝑖i-th edge server 𝒘isubscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}_{i}
Edge personalized model of i𝑖i-th edge server 𝝋isubscript𝝋𝑖\bm{\varphi}_{i}
Local edge model of i𝑖i-th edge server and j𝑗j-th client 𝝋i,jsubscript𝝋𝑖𝑗\bm{\varphi}_{i,j}
Local personalized model 𝜽i,jsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑗\bm{\theta}_{i,j}
Expected loss over the data of the i𝑖i-th server and j𝑗j-th client ℓi,jsubscriptℓ𝑖𝑗\ell_{i,j}
Training data of j𝑗j-th client in i𝑖i-th server Zi,jsubscript𝑍𝑖𝑗Z_{i,j}
Hyperparameter for sparsity γ1subscript𝛾1\gamma_{1}, γ2subscript𝛾2\gamma_{2}
Hyperparameter for personalization λ1subscript𝜆1\lambda_{1}, λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2}
Hyperparameter for aggregation β𝛽\beta
Global training round T𝑇T
Local training round R𝑅R
Number of edges to aggregate S𝑆S
Learning rate for updating 𝒘isubscript𝒘𝑖\bm{w}_{i} η1subscript𝜂1\eta_{1}
Learning rate for updating 𝜽i,jsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑗\bm{\theta}_{i,j} η2subscript𝜂2\eta_{2}

references: We present more detailed results for fine-tuning hyperparameters, including methods without a global model, in Tables II to V. Here, E𝐸E represents the number of edge servers in the hierarchical framework, and α𝛼\alpha represents the proportion of the client model that does not interact with the global model in HeurFedAMP. For HeurFedAMP, we tune α∈[0.1,0.5]𝛼0.10.5\alpha\in[0.1,0.5], where α𝛼\alpha represents the proportion of the client model that does not interact with the global model. For Fedprox, we tune λ∈{0.001,0.01,0.1,1}𝜆0.0010.010.11\lambda\in\{0.001,0.01,0.1,1\} following the setting in [18]. For pFedMe and sFedHP, we use the same setting as in [19] with λ∈{5,15,20,25,30}𝜆515202530\lambda\in\{5,15,20,25,30\}. For pFedGP, we use the same setting as in [22] for other basic hyperparameters. We find that sFedHP outperforms all compared algorithms in the global model (GM) and achieves state-of-the-art results in the personalized model (PM).

Fig. 2 shows the performance of sFedHP, hierarchical FedAvg and pFedMe in μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex situation. Since the MLR model is already lightweight enough, we set γ1=γ2=0subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾20\gamma_{1}=\gamma_{2}=0 for sFedHP. In Fig. 2, we can see that both sFedHP and pFedMe perform better than hierarchical FedAvg, while sFedHP obtain higher test accuracy and convergence speed, which shows that the hierarchical personalization scheme is more suitable for solving statistical diversity problem.

In summary, sFedHP performs better that pFedMe and hierarchical FedAvg in test accuracy, convergence rate, and communication cost in μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex and nonconvex situations. Furthermore, the hierarchical personalization scheme is more suitable for solving statistical diversity problems.

references: To empirically highlight the performance of the proposed method, we first compare

and local customization personalized FL methods, including
Fedprox
datasets. For non-i.i.d. setups, we follow the strategy in

clients and assign each client a unique local data with only 5 out of 10 labels. For client-edge-cloud framework, we set 4 edge servers and each edge server manages 5 clients. All 20 clients are selected to generate the global model in following experiments.

Furthermore, we use two different dataset split settings to validate the performance of the above algorithms. In Setting 1, we used 200, 200, 100 training samples and 800, 800, 400 test samples in each class for MNIST, FMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets respectively. In Setting 2, 900, 900, 450 training samples and 300, 300, 150 test samples are applied on MNIST, FMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets for each class. We use the DNN model with two hidden layers of size [500, 200] for MNIST/FMNIST datasets and the VGG model for CIFAR-10 dataset with “[16, ‘M’, 32, ‘M’, 64 ‘M’, 128, ‘M’, 128, ‘M’]” cfg setting. Each experiment is run at least 3 times to obtain statistical reports.

We found that hierarchical federated learning methods, such as sFedHP and HierFAVG, significantly outperformed other federated learning methods, including FedAvg, FedProx, and pFedMe, in the device-cloud structure on non-i.i.d. data. The proposed algorithm,
, outperforms the comparative algorithms concerning the global model in all settings by more than

clients and assign each client a unique local data with only 5 out of 10 labels. For client-edge-cloud framework, we set 4 edge servers and each edge server manages 5 clients. All 20 clients are selected to generate the global model in following experiments.

Furthermore, we use two different dataset split settings to validate the performance of the above algorithms. In Setting 1, we used 200, 200, 100 training samples and 800, 800, 400 test samples in each class for MNIST, FMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets respectively. In Setting 2, 900, 900, 450 training samples and 300, 300, 150 test samples are applied on MNIST, FMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets for each class. We use the DNN model with two hidden layers of size [500, 200] for MNIST/FMNIST datasets and the VGG model for CIFAR-10 dataset with “[16, ‘M’, 32, ‘M’, 64 ‘M’, 128, ‘M’, 128, ‘M’]” cfg setting. Each experiment is run at least 3 times to obtain statistical reports.

We found that hierarchical federated learning methods, such as sFedHP and HierFAVG, significantly outperformed other federated learning methods, including FedAvg, FedProx, and pFedMe, in the device-cloud structure on non-i.i.d. data.
